channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. They're looking for a Perl developer who has strong experience with payment networks, systems, and bank file formats.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer who has strong experience with both Perl and Python.

item.title: Forget the carrot and stick! Perl role in London
item.description: A titan of premium native advertising, our client dominates the field in sectors like tech, business, financial services, and lifestyle technology. They're looking for a Perl programmer who has commercial experience with one of Mojolicious / Catalyst / Dancer and experience with a front-end JavaScript framework, ideally React, but Angular or Vus.js considered too.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: Perl programmers, lean in — this is the opportunity for you if your happy place is at home in your fuzzy bunny slippers. The role is 100% remote friendly for those located in the UK, so kick back and enjoy your commute-free existence. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 129
item.description: I am a big fan of Simon style of blogging. He has the ability to say so much with few words. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 129: Eats Roots and Lists
item.description: Roger's love for Rust is all over in this week blog. Anyone interested in Rust, should definitely take a look. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 129
item.description: Full credit goes to Luis for the extra efforts he put in building tree structure. I admire his hard work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 129: trees and sums
item.description: Luca being a Raku lover, once again shared cool use of Raku class. Nice introduction to Raku class if you are new to Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #129
item.description: I loved the code re-use in this week contributions. It shows power of Perl. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: PWC129 - Add Linked Lists
item.description: Flavio being very kind in his observation about the task. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us every week.

item.title: PWC129 - Root Distance
item.description: Flavio continued his fun with Raku, There are plenty to learn every week by just reading his blog. You don't want to miss the fun ride.

item.title: 'List' Ain't Nothin' But 'Tree' Misspelled: The (Perl) Weekly Challenge #129
item.description: Dave using his nicely structured Node package to make the solution looks so easy. Well done. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Basic Data Structure Experiments with Object::Pad
item.description: Cheok-Yin shared the brilliant use of Object::Pad. I am impressed by the design and clarity. Keep it up.

item.title: Linked Roots with Raku
item.description: Arne has been great promoter of Raku language. In this week blog, he shared cool Raku magic once again. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 129: Add Linked Lists
item.description: Abigail ability to make difficult task looks simple is amazing. Plenty to learn from his contribution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 129: Root Distance
item.description: Abigail shared his magic as ever with bare minimum code. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 127
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 129
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Root Distance" and "Add Linked Lists" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 130
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Odd Number" and "Binary Search Tree". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: No voids, please
item.description: A small filtering program to rename files removing spaces and tabs.

item.title: Outreachy Perl internship 2021 successful completion
item.description: This year Rosheen Naeem was mentored by Stéphane Gigandet and worked on the Open Food Facts project. Which is looking for more contributors knowing Perl and people who like to eat.

item.title: Crop an image with ImageMagick
item.description: ImageMagick is an amazing set of command-line tools for doing image manipulation.

item.title: CPAN Release of Time::Verbal module
item.description: How do you say half past 8 in Klingon?

item.title: Fun with Advent of Code 2018
item.description: If you’re looking for some diversion or something to do some exercising (e.g. learning some Raku), Flavio suggests you giving Advent of Code a try.

item.title: Cutting the fat: Lightweight Perl OO modules
item.description: CPAN has a rich history of lighter-weight OO modules to meet many different needs. If you can live with their trade-offs, they're worth investigating instead of rolling your own layer over Perl's OO. Here are a few: Class::Struct, Class::Accessor, Class::Tiny, Object::Tiny, and more.

item.title: Advent of Code 2018, puzzle 6: get the job done!
Yancy: The Next Model
item.description: Yancy is a content management system and application framework for the Mojolicious web framework.

item.title: #529 - KöMaL for the math enthusiasts
item.description:
Hi there!

A long long time ago, when I was in high school, I participated in the annual competition of KöMaL, the Mathematical and Physical Journal for High Schools. (Look for the little UK flag for the English version). Back then we sent in the solution by snail-mail and we only had to write our name to be identified. However people with very common names were asked to include a 3-digit number between their names. There was no verification that two people with the exact same name did not pick the same number, but the chances were slim. Because my name is way too common in Hungary I picked the number 529 because it is 23^2. Funnily, if you squint it also resembles the initials of my name: SzG

Anyway, if you or your kids like math, informatics, or physics, I'd recommend it!

Enjoy your week!
